@x4base if you look at _caravel/data/**init**.py:def load_world_bank_health_n_pop()_ you'll see that data is uploaded to the server in chunks of 500 rows. Maybe bumping it to _2M_ would be enough. For reference on debian _max_allowed_packet_ is set by default to _16M_.

Or maybe this has been fixed here 7dd5b6716e44880f6481f0f454e415b545701503

@hongqp please post a backtrace otherwise it's quite difficult to understand what's going on. Also double check your conf.

@xrmx proper way (IMO)

```
-- Using default and 126 format for Datetime2
SELECT CONVERT(DATETIME2, '2015-08-10 11:58:47.123456', 126) as MSSQLDateTime2
-- Using default[:-3] and 121 format for Datetime 
SELECT CONVERT(DATETIME, '2015-08-10 11:58:47.123', 121) as MSSQLDateTime2
```

so
some changes in the code like:

```
def dttm_sql_literal(self, dttm, type):
        """Convert datetime object to string

        If database_expression is empty, the internal dttm
        will be parsed as the string with the pattern that
        the user inputted (python_date_format)
        If database_expression is not empty, the internal dttm
        will be parsed as the sql sentence for the database to convert
        """
        tf = self.python_date_format or '%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S.%f'
        if self.database_expression:
            return self.database_expression.format(dttm.strftime('%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S'))
        elif tf == 'epoch_s':
            return str((dttm - datetime(1970, 1, 1)).total_seconds())
        elif tf == 'epoch_ms':
            return str((dttm - datetime(1970, 1, 1)).total_seconds() * 1000.0)
        else:
            default = "'{}'".format(dttm.strftime(tf))
            iso = dttm.isoformat()
            d = {
                'mssql': "CONVERT({}, '{}', {})".
                            format("DATETIME2" if type.lower() == "datetime2" else "DATETIME",
                            default if type.lower() == "datetime2" else default[:- 3],
                            126 if type.lower() == "datetime2" else 121),  # untested
                'mysql': default,
                'oracle':
                    """TO_TIMESTAMP('{}', 'YYYY-MM-DD"T"HH24:MI:SS.ff6')""".format(iso),
                'presto': default,
                'sqlite': default,
            }
            for k, v in d.items():
                if self.table.database.sqlalchemy_uri.startswith(k):
                    return v
            return default
```

I think is this way I keep as much precision as possible with the definition the user has done.

Probably you are on Azure. Instance clean /tmp after restart. I have replaced sqlite with mysql backend for storing internal Caravel data.
Create /usr/local/etc/caravel_config.py:
ROW_LIMIT = 50000
CARAVEL_WORKERS = 16
CARAVEL_WEBSERVER_ADDRESS = '0.0.0.0'
CARAVEL_WEBSERVER_PORT = 8088
CARAVEL_WEBSERVER_TIMEOUT = 60
CUSTOM_SECURITY_MANAGER = None
SECRET_KEY = '\2\1changethis\1\2\e\y\y\h'
SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URI = 'mysql://root:changethis@localhost/caravel'
AUTH_USER_REGISTRATION = False
CACHE_CONFIG = {'CACHE_TYPE': 'RedisCache'}

Then export PYTHONPATH:
export PYTHONPATH=/usr/local/etc

Then run all setup steps again.

Yeah! totally agree with the "ifs" ;) was just playing around, sorry. Sadly I don't have an older SQL Server version to test the "default" behavior so I though CONVERT will be more backward compatible: http://www.techonthenet.com/sql_server/functions/convert.php (basically will cover SQL Server 2005)

Let me try again:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/767180/17552255/2553e1f0-5eff-11e6-8d13-402ee0984f86.png)
Ah, ok! yep you are right, for DATETIME2, CONVERT is not needed. Creating PR, talk later

For druid it's cheap and easy, it's a matter of running a topN query on a recent time range. 

If you were thinking about on the SQL side, you probably want a UI control that is a select multiple that is free form, and run some sort of 

```
select distinct val from(
  SELECT {col} FROM {table} LIMIT {some_constant_maybe_10k_ish}
) as qry
```

using the SqlAlchemy expression of course so it can be translated

The control would need to behave nicely event if the results haven't come back, maybe this feature can be enabled/disabled on a per-table basis?

That's a sweet feature! Seems superfluous at first but it definitely makes a huge difference.

I think the key is to cache that endpoint. If it's a free-form multi-choice select you can always enter your value by end if it's a new or long-tail value... 

The cloning part of the code is a bit nasty, feel free to redesign it if it's easy than working with it. Seems like the kind of stuff that would work nicely in React....
@xrmx Fixed tests and some coding style issues.
